text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen so the 
holiday season is coming up so today I'm going

to share with you a roast chicken with gravy 
recipe but it uses some of the most iconic

flavors of Thai cuisine so this is a great way to 
add a little bit of a Thai flavor to your holiday

table without it clashing with your traditional 
side dishes like your mashed potatoes and all that

because the flavors are really quite subtle but 
it's going to be super delicious let's get started

so we're gonna start first with the marinade now 
you could use my barbecue chicken marinade but

I'm going to show you a simpler version to keep 
the flavors a little more subtle so I've got both

black and white peppercorns here and always slots 
in a Thai marinade okay after that we're gonna go

in with some garlic and get that into a fine paste 
as well it's sort of a paste is not super fine but

I'm going to go in with my cilantro roots so this 
is what cilantro bruce'll like it's simply just

the roots of the cilantro plant if you can't find 
it cilantro stems are fine now I really want this

into a very fine paste and now I'm going to add 
some chopped up palm sugar and the sugar is going

to help cut the salt and also help with browning a 
little salt in there grind that up until the sugar

is dissolved and of course you can just throw 
everything in a blender if you want alright so

I've got some fish sauce and really the fish sauce 
is my only seasoning here and a lot of times in

Thai food fish sauce is the only seasoning you 
need but I'm going to add also a little bit of

black soy sauce or dark soy sauce and this will 
just help with color there we go and then finally

some water it'll help the chicken absorb some of 
that liquid a little bit like a quick brine keep

the meat juicy that is it that's the marinade all 
right so here's our chicken and first we're going

to butterfly the chicken also known as spatchcock 
the chicken that's removing the spine so we can

open the chicken up and it will marinate and roast 
more evenly and just going to cut the spine out

and it should be with good scissors relatively 
easy when you get to this by bone part it's gonna

feel a little bit hard because it's usually piece 
of fly bone there if you just sort of maneuver

the scissors inward a little bit you can usually 
cut around it and so there's usually a hard part

there and then once you get to this rib case it 
becomes easier from this point on I could have

also removed the wishbone first so there's one 
side and then you repeat the same on the other

side these scissors aren't as good as I hope they 
would be but it was only 499 so really what did I

expect yay okay we're gonna save the spine cuz 
we'll use it for the stock now when you open

up the chicken there's a little cartilage right 
there and so I'm going to just make a little slit

with my knife through the cartilage like that and 
press it open like a book and it should just sort

of flatten out like that okay and now we've 
opened up a whole bunch of surface area for

marinade penetration and it's also a little more 
interesting looking when you present it at the end

trim off all this big fatty bits this is going to 
produce a lot of fat in the roasting pan and then

you just have more to skim off when you make the 
gravy so I just go and trim off all the fat so I

am going to make sure the marinade gets under the 
skin especially the breast to make sure that it's

really really flavorful so all you have to do 
is stick your fingers underneath the skin and

just make a pocket and this is commonly done in 
western cuisines you may have done it before and

now I'm just going to add some of our marinade 
into each side of the breast and now you're just

going to sort of massage it through we're gonna 
do the same thing underneath the thigh skin and

this is why spatchcocking the chicken is also 
good because now you it's really easy to get the

marinade under the thigh skin and now I'm going 
to pour the rest of my marinade wrap the wings

rub everything we're going to let this marinate 
for 30 minutes that's all it takes is a strong

marinade and so this is why I love this recipe - 
you don't need to plan this days ahead of time and

then halfway through I'd like to just come back 
and redistribute the dressing give it another

rub and make sure everything is well evenly coated 
we're going to make the quick stock for the gravy

and so I've got the spine that we cut up notice 
that I removed the but because the bud is really

really fatty believe it or not in Thailand they 
sell deep fried chicken but I sort of like its

own thing but anyway too much fat so just water 
just enough to cover it I'm going to let this

simmer for about 20-30 minutes whatever you've got 
time for so now we're going to prep our herbs now

traditionally the western-style roast chicken 
gets stuffed with all sorts of herbs in the

cavity right so in a similar way that's what we're 
going to do but we're going to make a bed for the

chicken to lay on so I've got some lemongrass here 
and I'm actually going to also use the top which

we don't normally use so I'm going to remove the 
little end bit here and then just with the back of

my knife just smash there you go note I am using 
not the big roasting pan but just a quarter sheet

pan because the roasting pan I find the sides are 
too high and the sides will actually prevent heat

from circulating around the chicken evenly and so 
the bottom half of my chicken tends to not brown

as nicely so for this because our chicken is flat 
I prefer something with a shallower rim and then

my galangal is going in just on top now you don't 
have to have all the herbs I'm using some ginger

some lime leaves which I'm just going to tear into 
big chunks okay and then finally some shallots

which I chopped up but before I put the chicken 
on this herb bed I'm going to pour some water

on it and this water is going to help steam the 
herbs help the flavors come up and infuse into the

chicken better and it'll also prevent the chicken 
juices from burning too quickly and we're going

to put the chicken 1 2 3 up on this bit here big 
thighs this one has if you want you can tuck the

wings under here so they don't darken too quickly 
but I think right here is fine brush this chicken

with some oil and that's just to help the skin 
brown and crisp while the chicken is roasting

you want to keep your eyes on the pan once the 
liquid dries up and the bits on the pan starts

to brown you want to deglaze the pan a little bit 
with some water to prevent those bits from burning

because that is going to be part of the gravy 
that's better mmm all this liquid here if you

can see that's all good stuff that we're going 
to use as part of the gravy and that's all the

stuff that's got the herb flavor in it as well 
one two three hep whew okay I want to put all

the herbs on the bottom of the serving plate so 
that way when you serve it on the table people

sort of you know get a visual cue of what flavors 
went into this chicken right okay now is the best

part the gravy this is the spine that I've been 
simmering for about 20-30 minutes I'm just going

to remove it along with any sort of scum and fat 
that is floated to the top so now I'm going to add

the juices from the roasting of the chicken lots 
of good things going in here the marinade that we

had left over from the chicken don't throw that 
away we want to add the marinade right into here

match the flavor of the gravy to the flavor of 
the chicken and now I'm going to bring this to

a boil because we had raw chicken juice in there 
from the marinade so we want to make sure it's

all cooked off and you can skim this off a little 
more if you want it to and now what you want to

do is give it a taste and if it is too too thin 
sort of too diluted at this point let it reduce

a little bit so you get a more concentrated flavor 
mmm mmm oh I like that nice and peppery but I will

reduce it a little further it's a little weak 
that's good mmm that looks better already if you

have juices that's been collecting from under the 
chicken pour that in at this point because that's

all chicken juice chicken flavor without of course 
pouring the chicken right off this part is sort of

optional sort of not I'm going to add some coconut 
milk and I think it as definitely a touch of Thai

exotic flavor to it and you can add as much or 
as little of you as you want depending on how

strong of a coconut flavor you want a little bit 
more and now to thicken this gravy so I've got

some cornstarch here just enough water to dissolve 
the cornstarch you never add dry flour into a hot

liquid you will get lumps you will never be able 
to get out only half first and see where we're

at and you want to bring it back to a boil because 
that's how you know the cornstarch has reached its

full thickening power I'll show you a little trick 
that I do to make the gravy really serve dark and

rich I'm going to add some black soy sauce of 
course what else but now just look at that this

stuff is so useful very nice and also a little 
squeeze of lime now you don't want to make this

sour but right now it's very rich and luscious 
and the little squeeze of lime will brighten it

up a little bit sharpen it and they do this even 
in western style gravy really brightens everything

up mmm mmm that's good oh ho ho ho yeah check this 
out my god so one of the benefits of spatchcocking

your chicken is that it is so much easier to carve 
because it's sort of like that all the way there

ready for you to cut it open I am a thigh kind 
of girl I think y'all know that by now there we

go Oh smells so good just take a little bit here 
make sure it gets some skin boop there's almost

no such thing as too much gravy mmm mmm so tender 
and so flavorful and the gravy is rich in a little

bit coconutty it's subtle enough though that it's 
not going to clash if you wanted to have mashed

potatoes or roasted cauliflower or whatever it is 
so I hope you give it a try the recipe as always

is on Hut Titan calm and when you try it send 
me a photo I would love to see them and I will

include some of them in my newsletter and you 
can send those bows to me on Facebook Twitter

or Instagram and oh if you haven't subscribed 
to show here's the subscribe button here and I

will see you next time for your next delicious 
tiny tip this end that's it that's it down hey
